file.name: libvirt
file.summary: core interfaces for the libvirt library
file.description: Provides the interfaces of the libvirt library to handle virtualized domains
file.author: Daniel Veillard <veillard@redhat.com>

file.name: virterror
file.summary: error handling interfaces for the libvirt library
file.description: Provides the interfaces of the libvirt library to handle errors raised while using the library.
file.author: Daniel Veillard <veillard@redhat.com>

macro.name: LIBVIR_VERSION_NUMBER
macro.info: Macro providing the version of the library as version * 1,000,000 + minor * 1000 + micro

macro.name: VIR_COPY_CPUMAP
macro.info: This macro is to be used in conjunction with virDomainGetVcpus() and virDomainPinVcpu() APIs. VIR_COPY_CPUMAP macro extract the cpumap of the specified vcpu from cpumaps array and copy it into cpumap to be used later by virDomainPinVcpu() API.

arg.name: cpumaps
arg.info: pointer to an array of cpumap (in 8-bit bytes) (IN)

arg.name: maplen
arg.info: the length (in bytes) of one cpumap

arg.name: cpumap
arg.info: pointer to a cpumap (in 8-bit bytes) (OUT) This cpumap must be previously allocated by the caller (ie: malloc(maplen))

macro.name: VIR_CPU_MAPLEN
macro.info: This macro is to be used in conjunction with virDomainPinVcpu() API. It returns the length (in bytes) required to store the complete CPU map between a single virtual & all physical CPUs of a domain.

macro.name: VIR_CPU_USABLE
macro.info: This macro is to be used in conjunction with virDomainGetVcpus() API. VIR_CPU_USABLE macro returns a non zero value (true) if the cpu is usable by the vcpu, and 0 otherwise.

arg.name: cpumaps
arg.info: pointer to an array of cpumap (in 8-bit bytes) (IN)

arg.name: maplen
arg.info: the length (in bytes) of one cpumap

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BANDWIDTH_IN_AVERAGE
macro.info: Macro represents the inbound average of NIC bandwidth, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BANDWIDTH_IN_BURST
macro.info: Macro represents the inbound burst of NIC bandwidth, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BANDWIDTH_IN_PEAK
macro.info: Macro represents the inbound peak of NIC bandwidth, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BANDWIDTH_OUT_AVERAGE
macro.info: Macro represents the outbound average of NIC bandwidth, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BANDWIDTH_OUT_BURST
macro.info: Macro represents the outbound burst of NIC bandwidth, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BANDWIDTH_OUT_PEAK
macro.info: Macro represents the outbound peak of NIC bandwidth, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLKIO_DEVICE_WEIGHT
macro.info: Macro for the blkio tunable weight_device: it represents the per-device weight, as a string. The string is parsed as a series of /path/to/device,weight elements, separated by ','.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLKIO_FIELD_LENGTH
macro.info: Macro providing the field length of virBlkioParameter. Provided for backwards compatibility; VIR_TYPED_PARAM_FIELD_LENGTH is the preferred value since 0.9.2.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLKIO_WEIGHT
macro.info: Macro for the Blkio tunable weight: it represents the io weight the guest can use, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_IOTUNE_READ_BYTES_SEC
macro.info: Macro for the BlockIoTune tunable weight: it repersents the read bytes per second permitted through a block device, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_IOTUNE_READ_IOPS_SEC
macro.info: Macro for the BlockIoTune tunable weight: it repersents the read I/O operations per second permitted through a block device, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_IOTUNE_TOTAL_BYTES_SEC
macro.info: Macro for the BlockIoTune tunable weight: it represents the total bytes per second permitted through a block device, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_IOTUNE_TOTAL_IOPS_SEC
macro.info: Macro for the BlockIoTune tunable weight: it repersents the total I/O operations per second permitted through a block device, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_IOTUNE_WRITE_BYTES_SEC
macro.info: Macro for the BlockIoTune tunable weight: it repersents the write bytes per second permitted through a block device, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_IOTUNE_WRITE_IOPS_SEC
macro.info: Macro for the BlockIoTune tunable weight: it repersents the write I/O operations per second permitted through a block device, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_ERRS
macro.info: In Xen this returns the mysterious 'oo_req', as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_FIELD_LENGTH
macro.info: Macro providing the field length of parameter names when using virDomainBlockStatsFlags().

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_FLUSH_REQ
macro.info: Macro represents the total flush requests of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_FLUSH_TOTAL_TIMES
macro.info: Macro represents the total time spend on cache flushing in nano-seconds of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_READ_BYTES
macro.info: Macro represents the total number of read bytes of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_READ_REQ
macro.info: Macro represents the total read requests of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_READ_TOTAL_TIMES
macro.info: Macro represents the total time spend on cache reads in nano-seconds of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_WRITE_BYTES
macro.info: Macro represents the total number of write bytes of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_WRITE_REQ
macro.info: Macro represents the total write requests of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_STATS_WRITE_TOTAL_TIMES
macro.info: Macro represents the total time spend on cache writes in nano-seconds of the block device, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_CPU_STATS_CPUTIME
macro.info: cpu usage in nanoseconds, as a ullong

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_CPU_STATS_SYSTEMTIME
macro.info: cpu time charged to system instructions in nanoseconds, as a ullong

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_CPU_STATS_USERTIME
macro.info: cpu time charged to user instructions in nanoseconds, as a ullong

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_CALLBACK
macro.info: Used to cast the event specific callback into the generic one for use for virDomainEventRegister

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_FIELD_LENGTH
macro.info: Macro providing the field length of virMemoryParameter. Provided for backwards compatibility; VIR_TYPED_PARAM_FIELD_LENGTH is the preferred value since 0.9.2.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_HARD_LIMIT
macro.info: Macro for the memory tunable hard_limit: it represents the maximum memory the guest can use, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_MIN_GUARANTEE
macro.info: Macro for the memory tunable min_guarantee: it represents the minimum memory guaranteed to be reserved for the guest, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_PARAM_UNLIMITED
macro.info: Macro providing the virMemoryParameter value that indicates "unlimited"

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_SOFT_LIMIT
macro.info: Macro for the memory tunable soft_limit: it represents the memory upper limit enforced during memory contention, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_SWAP_HARD_LIMIT
macro.info: Macro for the swap tunable swap_hard_limit: it represents the maximum swap plus memory the guest can use, as a ullong. This limit has to be more than VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_HARD_LIMIT.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_NUMA_MODE
macro.info: Macro for typed parameter name that lists the numa mode of a domain, as an int containing a virDomainNumatuneMemMode value.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_NUMA_NODESET
macro.info: Macro for typed parameter name that lists the numa nodeset of a domain, as a string.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_CAP
macro.info: Macro represents the maximum scheduler cap, when using the credit scheduler, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_CPU_SHARES
macro.info: Macro represents proportional weight of the scheduler used on the host cpu, when using the posix scheduler, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_LIMIT
macro.info: Macro represents the scheduler limit value, when using the allocation scheduler, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_RESERVATION
macro.info: Macro represents the scheduler reservation value, when using the allocation scheduler, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_SHARES
macro.info: Macro represents the scheduler shares value, when using the allocation scheduler, as an int.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_VCPU_PERIOD
macro.info: Macro represents the enforcement period for a quota, in microseconds, when using the posix scheduler, as a ullong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_VCPU_QUOTA
macro.info: Macro represents the maximum bandwidth to be used within a period, when using the posix scheduler, as an llong.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHEDULER_WEIGHT
macro.info: Macro represents the relative weight, when using the credit scheduler, as a uint.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SCHED_FIELD_LENGTH
macro.info: Macro providing the field length of virSchedParameter. Provided for backwards compatibility; VIR_TYPED_PARAM_FIELD_LENGTH is the preferred value since 0.9.2.

macro.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SEND_KEY_MAX_KEYS
macro.info: Maximum number of keycodes that can be sent in one virDomainSendKey() call.

macro.name: VIR_GET_CPUMAP
macro.info: This macro is to be used in conjunction with virDomainGetVcpus() and virDomainPinVcpu() APIs. VIR_GET_CPUMAP macro returns a pointer to the cpumap of the specified vcpu from cpumaps array.

arg.name: cpumaps
arg.info: pointer to an array of cpumap (in 8-bit bytes) (IN)

arg.name: maplen
arg.info: the length (in bytes) of one cpumap

macro.name: VIR_NODEINFO_MAXCPUS
macro.info: This macro is to calculate the total number of CPUs supported but not necessary active in the host.

macro.name: VIR_NODE_CPU_STATS_FIELD_LENGTH
macro.info: Macro providing the field length of virNodeCPUStats

macro.name: VIR_NODE_CPU_STATS_IDLE
macro.info: The cumulative idle CPU time, since the node booting up (in nanoseconds).

macro.name: VIR_NODE_CPU_STATS_IOWAIT
macro.info: The cumulative I/O wait CPU time, since the node booting up (in nanoseconds).

macro.name: VIR_NODE_CPU_STATS_KERNEL
macro.info: Macro for the cumulative CPU time which was spent by the kernel, since the node booting up (in nanoseconds).

macro.name: VIR_NODE_CPU_STATS_USER
macro.info: The cumulative CPU time which was spent by user processes, since the node booting up (in nanoseconds).

macro.name: VIR_NODE_CPU_STATS_UTILIZATION
macro.info: The CPU utilization of a node. The usage value is in percent and 100% represents all CPUs of the node.

macro.name: VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_BUFFERS
macro.info: Macro for the buffer memory: On Linux, it is only returned in case of VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_ALL_CELLS.

macro.name: VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_CACHED
macro.info: Macro for the cached memory: On Linux, it is only returned in case of VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_ALL_CELLS.

macro.name: VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_FIELD_LENGTH
macro.info: Macro providing the field length of virNodeMemoryStats

macro.name: VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_FREE
macro.info: Macro for the free memory of specified cell: On Linux, it includes buffer and cached memory, in case of VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_ALL_CELLS.

macro.name: VIR_NODE_MEMORY_STATS_TOTAL
macro.info: Macro for the total memory of specified cell: it represents the maximum memory.

macro.name: VIR_SECURITY_DOI_BUFLEN
macro.info: Macro providing the maximum length of the virSecurityModel doi string.

macro.name: VIR_SECURITY_LABEL_BUFLEN
macro.info: Macro providing the maximum length of the virSecurityLabel label string. Note that this value is based on that used by Labeled NFS.

macro.name: VIR_SECURITY_MODEL_BUFLEN
macro.info: Macro providing the maximum length of the virSecurityModel model string.

macro.name: VIR_TYPED_PARAM_FIELD_LENGTH
macro.info: Macro providing the field length of virTypedParameter name

macro.name: VIR_UNUSE_CPU
macro.info: This macro is to be used in conjunction with virDomainPinVcpu() API. USE_CPU macro reset the bit (CPU not usable) of the related cpu in cpumap.

arg.name: cpumap
arg.info: pointer to a bit map of real CPUs (in 8-bit bytes) (IN/OUT)

macro.name: VIR_USE_CPU
macro.info: This macro is to be used in conjunction with virDomainPinVcpu() API. USE_CPU macro set the bit (CPU usable) of the related cpu in cpumap.

arg.name: cpumap
arg.info: pointer to a bit map of real CPUs (in 8-bit bytes) (IN/OUT)

macro.name: VIR_UUID_BUFLEN
macro.info: This macro provides the length of the buffer required for virDomainGetUUID()

macro.name: VIR_UUID_STRING_BUFLEN
macro.info: This macro provides the length of the buffer required for virDomainGetUUIDString()

enum.name: VIR_CONNECT_NO_ALIASES
enum.info: Don't try to resolve URI aliases

enum.name: VIR_CRED_EXTERNAL
enum.info: Externally managed credential More may be added - expect the unexpected

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CONFIG
enum.info: Affect persistent domain state. 1 << 2 is reserved for virTypedParameterFlags

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCKED
enum.info: the domain is blocked on resource

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_RESIZE_BYTES
enum.info: size in bytes instead of KiB

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_CONSOLE_FORCE
enum.info: abort a (possibly) active console connection to force a new connection

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_CONSOLE_SAFE
enum.info: check if the console driver supports safe console operations

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_CONTROL_ERROR
enum.info: unusable, domain cannot be fully operated

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_CONTROL_JOB
enum.info: background job is running (can be monitored by virDomainGetJobInfo); only limited set of commands may be allowed

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_DESTROY_DEFAULT
enum.info: Default behavior - could lead to data loss!!

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_DEVICE_MODIFY_CONFIG
enum.info: Additionally, these flags may be bitwise-OR'd in.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_DEVICE_MODIFY_FORCE
enum.info: Forcibly modify device (ex. force eject a cdrom)

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_DISK_ERROR_NO_SPACE
enum.info: no space left on the device

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_ID_PMSUSPEND
enum.info: NB: this enum value will increase over time as new events are added to the libvirt API. It reflects the last event ID supported by this version of the libvirt API.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_IO_ERROR_REPORT
enum.info: IO error reported to guest OS

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_RESUMED_UNPAUSED
enum.info: Normal resume due to admin unpause

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_SUSPENDED_IOERROR
enum.info: Suspended due to a disk I/O error

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_SUSPENDED_PAUSED
enum.info: Normal suspend due to admin pause

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_SUSPENDED_WATCHDOG
enum.info: Suspended due to a watchdog firing

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_WATCHDOG_DEBUG
enum.info: No action, a debug message logged

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_WATCHDOG_SHUTDOWN
enum.info: Guest is requested to gracefully shutdown

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_BOUNDED
enum.info: Job with a finite completion time

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_CANCELLED
enum.info: Job was aborted, but isn't cleaned up

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_COMPLETED
enum.info: Job has finished, but isn't cleaned up

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_FAILED
enum.info: Job hit error, but isn't cleaned up

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED
enum.info: Job without a finite completion time

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_STAT_ACTUAL_BALLOON
enum.info: Resident Set Size of the process running the domain. This value is in kB

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_STAT_MINOR_FAULT
enum.info: The amount of memory left completely unused by the system. Memory that is available but used for reclaimable caches should NOT be reported as free. This value is expressed in kB.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_STAT_RSS
enum.info: The number of statistics supported by this version of the interface. To add new statistics, add them to the enum and increase this value.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_STAT_SWAP_IN
enum.info: The total amount of memory written out to swap space (in kB).

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_STAT_SWAP_OUT
enum.info: Page faults occur when a process makes a valid access to virtual memory that is not available. When servicing the page fault, if disk IO is required, it is considered a major fault. If not, it is a minor fault. These are expressed as the number of faults that have occurred.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEMORY_STAT_UNUSED
enum.info: The total amount of usable memory as seen by the domain. This value may be less than the amount of memory assigned to the domain if a balloon driver is in use or if the guest OS does not initialize all assigned pages. This value is expressed in kB.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_MEM_CONFIG
enum.info: Additionally, these flags may be bitwise-OR'd in.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_NUMATUNE_MEM_INTERLEAVE
enum.info: This constant is subject to change

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_PAUSED
enum.info: the domain is paused by user

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_PAUSED_IOERROR
enum.info: paused due to a disk I/O error

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_PAUSED_WATCHDOG
enum.info: paused due to a watchdog event

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_PMSUSPENDED
enum.info: NB: this enum value will increase over time as new events are added to the libvirt API. It reflects the last state supported by this version of the libvirt API.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_RUNNING_WAKEUP
enum.info: returned from pmsuspended due to wakeup event

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SHUTDOWN
enum.info: the domain is being shut down

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SHUTOFF_FROM_SNAPSHOT
enum.info: restored from a snapshot which was taken while domain was shutoff

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SNAPSHOT_CREATE_QUIESCE
enum.info: use guest agent to quiesce all mounted file systems within the domain

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SNAPSHOT_LIST_DESCENDANTS
enum.info: List all descendants, not just children, when listing a snapshot

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SNAPSHOT_LIST_LEAVES
enum.info: Filter by snapshots with no children

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SNAPSHOT_LIST_METADATA
enum.info: Filter by snapshots which have metadata

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_SNAPSHOT_LIST_ROOTS
enum.info: Filter by snapshots with no parents, when listing a domain

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_START_AUTODESTROY
enum.info: Automatically kill guest when virConnectPtr is closed

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_UNDEFINE_SNAPSHOTS_METADATA
enum.info: If last use of domain, then also remove any snapshot metadata Future undefine control flags should come here.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_VCPU_CONFIG
enum.info: Additionally, these flags may be bitwise-OR'd in.

enum.name: VIR_DOMAIN_XML_UPDATE_CPU
enum.info: update guest CPU requirements according to host CPU

enum.name: VIR_ERR_ARGUMENT_UNSUPPORTED
enum.info: valid API use but unsupported by the given driver

enum.name: VIR_ERR_CONF_SYNTAX
enum.info: failed to parse the syntax of a conf file

enum.name: VIR_ERR_GET_FAILED
enum.info: a HTTP GET command to failed

enum.name: VIR_ERR_MIGRATE_PERSIST_FAILED
enum.info: a migration worked, but making the VM persist on the dest host failed

enum.name: VIR_ERR_MULTIPLE_INTERFACES
enum.info: more than one matching interface found

enum.name: VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN
enum.info: domain not found or unexpectedly disappeared

enum.name: VIR_ERR_NO_XEN
enum.info: could not open Xen hypervisor control

enum.name: VIR_ERR_NO_XENSTORE
enum.info: could not open Xen Store control

enum.name: VIR_ERR_OPEN_FAILED
enum.info: failed to open a conf file

enum.name: VIR_ERR_OPERATION_ABORTED
enum.info: operation on a domain was canceled/aborted by user

enum.name: VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID
enum.info: operation is not applicable at this time

enum.name: VIR_ERR_PARSE_FAILED
enum.info: failed to parse a conf file

enum.name: VIR_ERR_POST_FAILED
enum.info: a HTTP POST command to failed

enum.name: VIR_ERR_READ_FAILED
enum.info: failed to read a conf file

enum.name: VIR_ERR_SNAPSHOT_REVERT_RISKY
enum.info: force was not requested for a risky domain snapshot revert

enum.name: VIR_ERR_WRITE_FAILED
enum.info: failed to write a conf file

enum.name: VIR_ERR_XML_ERROR
enum.info: an XML description is not well formed or broken

enum.name: VIR_FROM_CONF
enum.info: Error in the configuration file handling

enum.name: VIR_FROM_DOM
enum.info: Error when operating on a domain

enum.name: VIR_FROM_INTERFACE
enum.info: Error when operating on an interface

enum.name: VIR_FROM_NET
enum.info: Error when operating on a network

enum.name: VIR_FROM_ONE
enum.info: The OpenNebula driver no longer exists. Retained for ABI/API compat only

enum.name: VIR_FROM_PROXY
enum.info: Error in the proxy code; unused since 0.8.6

enum.name: VIR_FROM_STATS_LINUX
enum.info: Error in the Linux Stats code

enum.name: VIR_FROM_XEND
enum.info: Error at connection with xend daemon

enum.name: VIR_FROM_XENSTORE
enum.info: Error at connection with xen store

enum.name: VIR_KEYCODE_SET_RFB
enum.info: NB: this enum value will increase over time as new events are added to the libvirt API. It reflects the last keycode set supported by this version of the libvirt API.

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_CHANGE_PROTECTION
enum.info: protect for changing domain configuration through the whole migration process; this will be used automatically when supported

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_NON_SHARED_DISK
enum.info: migration with non-shared storage with full disk copy

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_NON_SHARED_INC
enum.info: migration with non-shared storage with incremental copy (same base image shared between source and destination)

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_PEER2PEER
enum.info: direct source -> dest host control channel Note the less-common spelling that we're stuck with: VIR_MIGRATE_TUNNELLED should be VIR_MIGRATE_TUNNELED

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_PERSIST_DEST
enum.info: persist the VM on the destination

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_TUNNELLED
enum.info: tunnel migration data over libvirtd connection

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_UNDEFINE_SOURCE
enum.info: undefine the VM on the source

enum.name: VIR_MIGRATE_UNSAFE
enum.info: force migration even if it is considered unsafe

enum.name: VIR_NODE_SUSPEND_TARGET_HYBRID
enum.info: This constant is subject to change

enum.name: VIR_SECRET_USAGE_TYPE_CEPH
enum.info: NB: this enum value will increase over time as new events are added to the libvirt API. It reflects the last secret owner ID supported by this version of the libvirt API.

enum.name: VIR_STORAGE_VOL_WIPE_ALG_BSI
enum.info: 9-pass method recommended by the German Center of Security in Information Technologies

enum.name: VIR_STORAGE_VOL_WIPE_ALG_RANDOM
enum.info: NB: this enum value will increase over time as new algorithms are added to the libvirt API. It reflects the last algorithm supported by this version of the libvirt API.

enum.name: VIR_STORAGE_VOL_WIPE_ALG_SCHNEIER
enum.info: 7-pass method described by Bruce Schneier in "Applied Cryptography" (1996)

enum.name: VIR_VCPU_BLOCKED
enum.info: the virtual CPU is blocked on resource

field.name: s
field.info: type is STRING, may not be NULL

typedef.name: virBlkioParameterPtr
typedef.info: a virBlkioParameterPtr is a pointer to a virBlkioParameter structure. Provided for backwards compatibility; virTypedParameterPtr is the preferred alias since 0.9.2.

field.name: result
field.info: Result to be filled with user response (or defresult)

typedef.name: virConnectPtr
typedef.info: a virConnectPtr is pointer to a virConnect private structure, this is the type used to reference a connection to the Hypervisor in the API.

field.name: capacity
field.info: logical size in bytes of the block device backing image

field.name: allocation
field.info: highest allocated extent in bytes of the block device backing image

field.name: physical
field.info: physical size in bytes of the container of the backing image

field.name: bandwidth
field.info: The following fields provide an indication of block job progress. @cur indicates the current position and will be between 0 and @end. @end is the final cursor position for this operation and represents completion. To approximate progress, divide @cur by @end.

typedef.name: virDomainBlockStatsPtr
typedef.info: A pointer to a virDomainBlockStats structure

field.name: errs
field.info: In Xen this returns the mysterious 'oo_req'.

field.name: stateTime
field.info: for how long (in msec) control interface has been in current state (except for OK and ERROR states)

typedef.name: virDomainControlInfoPtr
typedef.info: Pointer to virDomainControlInfo structure.

field.name: node
field.info: Address of node (eg IP address, or UNIX path)

field.name: service
field.info: Service name/number (eg TCP port, or NULL)

field.name: state
field.info: the running state, one of virDomainState

field.name: maxMem
field.info: the maximum memory in KBytes allowed

field.name: memory
field.info: the memory in KBytes used by the domain

field.name: nrVirtCpu
field.info: the number of virtual CPUs for the domain

field.name: cpuTime
field.info: the CPU time used in nanoseconds

typedef.name: virDomainInfoPtr
typedef.info: a virDomainInfoPtr is a pointer to a virDomainInfo structure.

typedef.name: virDomainInterfaceStatsPtr
typedef.info: A pointer to a virDomainInterfaceStats structure

field.name: timeRemaining
field.info:
Only for VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_BOUNDED Data is measured in bytes unless otherwise specified and is measuring the job as a whole
For VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED, dataTotal may be less than the final sum of dataProcessed + dataRemaining in the event that the hypervisor has to repeat some data eg due to dirtied pages during migration
For VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_BOUNDED, dataTotal shall always equal sum of dataProcessed + dataRemaining

field.name: dataRemaining
field.info: As above, but only tracking guest memory progress

field.name: memRemaining
field.info: As above, but only tracking guest disk file progress

function.name: virConnCopyLastError
function.info:
Copy the content of the last error caught on that connection
This method is not protected against access from multiple threads. In a multi-threaded application, always use the global virGetLastError() API which is backed by thread local storage.
If the connection object was discovered to be invalid by an API call, then the error will be reported against the global error object.
Since 0.6.0, all errors reported in the per-connection object are also duplicated in the global error object. As such an application can always use virGetLastError(). This method remains for backwards compatibility.
One will need to free the result with virResetError()

return.info: 0 if no error was found and the error code otherwise and -1 in case of parameter error.

function.name: virConnGetLastError
function.info:
Provide a pointer to the last error caught on that connection
This method is not protected against access from multiple threads. In a multi-threaded application, always use the global virGetLastError() API which is backed by thread local storage.
If the connection object was discovered to be invalid by an API call, then the error will be reported against the global error object.
Since 0.6.0, all errors reported in the per-connection object are also duplicated in the global error object. As such an application can always use virGetLastError(). This method remains for backwards compatibility.

return.info: a pointer to the last error or NULL if none occurred.

function.name: virConnResetLastError
function.info:
The error object is kept in thread local storage, so separate threads can safely access this concurrently.
Reset the last error caught on that connection

function.name: virConnSetErrorFunc
function.info: Set a connection error handling function, if @handler is NULL it will reset to default which is to pass error back to the global library handler.

arg.name: userData

arg.name: handler
arg.info: the function to get called in case of error or NULL

return.info: 0 if all interactions were filled, or -1 upon error

function.info: Computes the most feature-rich CPU which is compatible with all given host CPUs.

return.info: XML description of the computed CPU or NULL on error.

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virConnectClose
function.info:
This function closes the connection to the Hypervisor. This should not be called if further interaction with the Hypervisor are needed especially if there is running domain which need further monitoring by the application.
Connections are reference counted; the count is explicitly increased by the initial open (virConnectOpen, virConnectOpenAuth, and the like) as well as virConnectRef; it is also temporarily increased by other API that depend on the connection remaining alive. The open and every virConnectRef call should have a matching virConnectClose, and all other references will be released after the corresponding operation completes.

return.info: the number of remaining references on success (positive implies that some other call still has a reference open, 0 implies that no references remain and the connection is closed), or -1 on failure. It is possible for the last virConnectClose to return a positive value if some other object still has a temporary reference to the connection, but the application should not try to further use a connection after the virConnectClose that matches the initial open.

function.name: virConnectDomainEventRegister
function.info:
Adds a callback to receive notifications of domain lifecycle events occurring on a connection
Use of this method is no longer recommended. Instead applications should try virConnectDomainEventRegisterAny which has a more flexible API contract
The virDomainPtr object handle passed into the callback upon delivery of an event is only valid for the duration of execution of the callback. If the callback wishes to keep the domain object after the callback returns, it shall take a reference to it, by calling virDomainRef. The reference can be released once the object is no longer required by calling virDomainFree.

return.info: 0 on success, -1 on failure

arg.name: cb
arg.info: callback to the function handling domain events

arg.name: opaque
arg.info: opaque data to pass on to the callback

arg.name: freecb
arg.info: optional function to deallocate opaque when not used anymore

function.name: virConnectDomainEventRegisterAny
function.info:
Adds a callback to receive notifications of arbitrary domain events occurring on a domain.
If dom is NULL, then events will be monitored for any domain. If dom is non-NULL, then only the specific domain will be monitored
Most types of event have a callback providing a custom set of parameters for the event. When registering an event, it is thus necessary to use the VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_CALLBACK() macro to cast the supplied function pointer to match the signature of this method.
The virDomainPtr object handle passed into the callback upon delivery of an event is only valid for the duration of execution of the callback. If the callback wishes to keep the domain object after the callback returns, it shall take a reference to it, by calling virDomainRef. The reference can be released once the object is no longer required by calling virDomainFree.
The return value from this method is a positive integer identifier for the callback. To unregister a callback, this callback ID should be passed to the virDomainEventUnregisterAny method

return.info: a callback identifier on success, -1 on failure

arg.name: cb
arg.info: callback to the function handling domain events

arg.name: opaque
arg.info: opaque data to pass on to the callback

arg.name: freecb
arg.info: optional function to deallocate opaque when not used anymore

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virConnectFindStoragePoolSources
function.info:
Talks to a storage backend and attempts to auto-discover the set of available storage pool sources. e.g. For iSCSI this would be a set of iSCSI targets. For NFS this would be a list of exported paths. The srcSpec (optional for some storage pool types, e.g. local ones) is an instance of the storage pool's source element specifying where to look for the pools.
srcSpec is not required for some types (e.g., those querying local storage resources only)

return.info: an xml document consisting of a SourceList element containing a source document appropriate to the given pool type for each discovered source.

arg.name: type
arg.info: type of storage pool sources to discover

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virConnectGetCapabilities
function.info: Provides capabilities of the hypervisor / driver.

return.info: NULL in case of error, or an XML string defining the capabilities. The client must free the returned string after use.

function.name: virConnectGetHostname
function.info: This returns the system hostname on which the hypervisor is running (the result of the gethostname system call). If we are connected to a remote system, then this returns the hostname of the remote system.

return.info: the hostname which must be freed by the caller, or NULL if there was an error.

function.name: virConnectGetLibVersion
function.info: Provides @libVer, which is the version of libvirt used by the daemon running on the @conn host

return.info: -1 in case of failure, 0 otherwise, and values for @libVer have the format major * 1,000,000 + minor * 1,000 + release.

arg.name: libVer
arg.info: returns the libvirt library version used on the connection (OUT)

function.name: virConnectGetMaxVcpus
function.info: Provides the maximum number of virtual CPUs supported for a guest VM of a specific type. The 'type' parameter here corresponds to the 'type' attribute in the <domain> element of the XML.

return.info: the maximum of virtual CPU or -1 in case of error.

arg.name: type
arg.info: value of the 'type' attribute in the <domain> element

function.name: virConnectGetSysinfo
function.info: This returns the XML description of the sysinfo details for the host on which the hypervisor is running, in the same format as the <sysinfo> element of a domain XML. This information is generally available only for hypervisors running with root privileges.

return.info: the XML string which must be freed by the caller, or NULL if there was an error.

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virConnectGetType
function.info: Get the name of the Hypervisor software used.

return.info: NULL in case of error, a static zero terminated string otherwise. See also: http://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2007-February/msg00096.html

function.name: virConnectGetURI
function.info: This returns the URI (name) of the hypervisor connection. Normally this is the same as or similar to the string passed to the virConnectOpen/virConnectOpenReadOnly call, but the driver may make the URI canonical. If name == NULL was passed to virConnectOpen, then the driver will return a non-NULL URI which can be used to connect to the same hypervisor later.

return.info: the URI string which must be freed by the caller, or NULL if there was an error.

function.name: virConnectGetVersion
function.info: Get the version level of the Hypervisor running. This may work only with hypervisor call, i.e. with privileged access to the hypervisor, not with a Read-Only connection.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 otherwise. if the version can't be extracted by lack of capacities returns 0 and @hvVer is 0, otherwise @hvVer value is major * 1,000,000 + minor * 1,000 + release

arg.name: hvVer
arg.info: return value for the version of the running hypervisor (OUT)

function.name: virConnectIsAlive
function.info:
Determine if the connection to the hypervisor is still alive
A connection will be classed as alive if it is either local, or running over a channel (TCP or UNIX socket) which is not closed.

return.info: 1 if alive, 0 if dead, -1 on error

function.name: virConnectIsEncrypted
function.info: Determine if the connection to the hypervisor is encrypted

return.info: 1 if encrypted, 0 if not encrypted, -1 on error

function.name: virConnectIsSecure
function.info:
Determine if the connection to the hypervisor is secure
A connection will be classed as secure if it is either encrypted, or running over a channel which is not exposed to eavesdropping (eg a UNIX domain socket, or pipe)

return.info: 1 if secure, 0 if secure, -1 on error

function.name: virConnectOpen
function.info: This function should be called first to get a connection to the Hypervisor and xen store

return.info: a pointer to the hypervisor connection or NULL in case of error If @name is NULL, if the LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI environment variable is set, then it will be used. Otherwise if the client configuration file has the "uri_default" parameter set, then it will be used. Finally probing will be done to determine a suitable default driver to activate. This involves trying each hypervisor in turn until one successfully opens. If connecting to an unprivileged hypervisor driver which requires the libvirtd daemon to be active, it will automatically be launched if not already running. This can be prevented by setting the environment variable LIBVIRT_AUTOSTART=0 URIs are documented at http://libvirt.org/uri.html

function.name: virConnectOpenAuth
function.info:
This function should be called first to get a connection to the Hypervisor. If necessary, authentication will be performed fetching credentials via the callback
See virConnectOpen for notes about environment variables which can have an effect on opening drivers

return.info: a pointer to the hypervisor connection or NULL in case of error URIs are documented at http://libvirt.org/uri.html

function.name: virConnectOpenReadOnly
function.info:
This function should be called first to get a restricted connection to the library functionalities. The set of APIs usable are then restricted on the available methods to control the domains.
See virConnectOpen for notes about environment variables which can have an effect on opening drivers

return.info: a pointer to the hypervisor connection or NULL in case of error URIs are documented at http://libvirt.org/uri.html

function.name: virConnectRef
function.info:
Increment the reference count on the connection. For each additional call to this method, there shall be a corresponding call to virConnectClose to release the reference count, once the caller no longer needs the reference to this object.
This method is typically useful for applications where multiple threads are using a connection, and it is required that the connection remain open until all threads have finished using it. ie, each new thread using a connection would increment the reference count.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of failure

arg.name: conn
arg.info: the connection to hold a reference on

function.name: virConnectSetKeepAlive
function.info:
Start sending keepalive messages after interval second of inactivity and consider the connection to be broken when no response is received after count keepalive messages sent in a row. In other words, sending count + 1 keepalive message results in closing the connection. When interval is <= 0, no keepalive messages will be sent. When count is 0, the connection will be automatically closed after interval seconds of inactivity without sending any keepalive messages.
Note: client has to implement and run event loop to be able to use keepalive messages. Failure to do so may result in connections being closed unexpectedly.

return.info: -1 on error, 0 on success, 1 when remote party doesn't support keepalive messages.

arg.name: interval
arg.info: number of seconds of inactivity before a keepalive message is sent

arg.name: count
arg.info: number of messages that can be sent in a row

function.name: virCopyLastError
function.info:
Copy the content of the last error caught at the library level
The error object is kept in thread local storage, so separate threads can safely access this concurrently.
One will need to free the result with virResetError()

return.info: 0 if no error was found and the error code otherwise and -1 in case of parameter error.

function.name: virDefaultErrorFunc
function.info: Default routine reporting an error to stderr.

function.name: virDomainAbortJob
function.info: Requests that the current background job be aborted at the soonest opportunity. This will block until the job has either completed, or aborted.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

function.name: virDomainAttachDevice
function.info:
Create a virtual device attachment to backend. This function, having hotplug semantics, is only allowed on an active domain.
For compatibility, this method can also be used to change the media in an existing CDROM/Floppy device, however, applications are recommended to use the virDomainUpdateDeviceFlag method instead.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: xml
arg.info: pointer to XML description of one device

function.name: virDomainAttachDeviceFlags
function.info:
Attach a virtual device to a domain, using the flags parameter to control how the device is attached. VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CURRENT specifies that the device allocation is made based on current domain state. VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_LIVE specifies that the device shall be allocated to the active domain instance only and is not added to the persisted domain configuration. VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CONFIG specifies that the device shall be allocated to the persisted domain configuration only. Note that the target hypervisor must return an error if unable to satisfy flags. E.g. the hypervisor driver will return failure if LIVE is specified but it only supports modifying the persisted device allocation.
For compatibility, this method can also be used to change the media in an existing CDROM/Floppy device, however, applications are recommended to use the virDomainUpdateDeviceFlag method instead.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: xml
arg.info: pointer to XML description of one device

function.name: virDomainBlockJobAbort
function.info:
Cancel the active block job on the given disk.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or (since 0.9.5) the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.

return.info: -1 in case of failure, 0 when successful.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainBlockJobSetSpeed
function.info:
Set the maximimum allowable bandwidth that a block job may consume. If bandwidth is 0, the limit will revert to the hypervisor default.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or (since 0.9.5) the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.

return.info: -1 in case of failure, 0 when successful.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainBlockPeek
function.info:
This function allows you to read the contents of a domain's disk device.
Typical uses for this are to determine if the domain has written a Master Boot Record (indicating that the domain has completed installation), or to try to work out the state of the domain's filesystems.
(Note that in the local case you might try to open the block device or file directly, but that won't work in the remote case, nor if you don't have sufficient permission. Hence the need for this call).
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or (since 0.9.5) the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.
'offset' and 'size' represent an area which must lie entirely within the device or file. 'size' may be 0 to test if the call would succeed.
'buffer' is the return buffer and must be at least 'size' bytes.
NB. The remote driver imposes a 64K byte limit on 'size'. For your program to be able to work reliably over a remote connection you should split large requests to <= 65536 bytes.

return.info: 0 in case of success or -1 in case of failure. really 64 bits

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: buffer
arg.info: return buffer (must be at least size bytes)

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainBlockPull
function.info:
Populate a disk image with data from its backing image. Once all data from its backing image has been pulled, the disk no longer depends on a backing image. This function pulls data for the entire device in the background. Progress of the operation can be checked with virDomainGetBlockJobInfo() and the operation can be aborted with virDomainBlockJobAbort(). When finished, an asynchronous event is raised to indicate the final status.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or (since 0.9.5) the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.
The maximum bandwidth (in Mbps) that will be used to do the copy can be specified with the bandwidth parameter. If set to 0, libvirt will choose a suitable default. Some hypervisors do not support this feature and will return an error if bandwidth is not 0.
This is shorthand for virDomainBlockRebase() with a NULL base.

return.info: 0 if the operation has started, -1 on failure.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: bandwidth
arg.info: (optional) specify copy bandwidth limit in Mbps

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainBlockRebase
function.info:
Populate a disk image with data from its backing image chain, and setting the backing image to @base. @base must be the absolute path of one of the backing images further up the chain, or NULL to convert the disk image so that it has no backing image. Once all data from its backing image chain has been pulled, the disk no longer depends on those intermediate backing images. This function pulls data for the entire device in the background. Progress of the operation can be checked with virDomainGetBlockJobInfo() and the operation can be aborted with virDomainBlockJobAbort(). When finished, an asynchronous event is raised to indicate the final status.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.
The maximum bandwidth (in Mbps) that will be used to do the copy can be specified with the bandwidth parameter. If set to 0, libvirt will choose a suitable default. Some hypervisors do not support this feature and will return an error if bandwidth is not 0.
When @base is NULL, this is identical to virDomainBlockPull().

return.info: 0 if the operation has started, -1 on failure.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: base
arg.info: path to backing file to keep, or NULL for no backing file

arg.name: bandwidth
arg.info: (optional) specify copy bandwidth limit in Mbps

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainBlockResize
function.info:
Resize a block device of domain while the domain is running. If @flags is 0, then @size is in kibibytes (blocks of 1024 bytes); since 0.9.11, if @flags includes VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_RESIZE_BYTES, @size is in bytes instead. @size is taken directly as the new size. Depending on the file format, the hypervisor may round up to the next alignment boundary.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or (since 0.9.5) the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.
Note that this call may fail if the underlying virtualization hypervisor does not support it; this call requires privileged access to the hypervisor.

return.info: 0 in case of success or -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block image, or shorthand

arg.name: size
arg.info: new size of the block image, see below for unit

function.name: virDomainBlockStats
function.info:
This function returns block device (disk) stats for block devices attached to the domain.
The @disk parameter is either the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"), or (since 0.9.8) an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.
Domains may have more than one block device. To get stats for each you should make multiple calls to this function.
Individual fields within the stats structure may be returned as -1, which indicates that the hypervisor does not support that particular statistic.

return.info: 0 in case of success or -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

function.name: virDomainBlockStatsFlags
function.info:
This function is to get block stats parameters for block devices attached to the domain.
The @disk parameter is either the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"), or (since 0.9.8) an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.
Domains may have more than one block device. To get stats for each you should make multiple calls to this function.
On input, @nparams gives the size of the @params array; on output, @nparams gives how many slots were filled with parameter information, which might be less but will not exceed the input value.
As a special case, calling with @params as NULL and @nparams as 0 on input will cause @nparams on output to contain the number of parameters supported by the hypervisor. (Note that block devices of different types might support different parameters, so it might be necessary to compute @nparams for each block device). The caller should then allocate @params array, i.e. (sizeof(@virTypedParameter) * @nparams) bytes and call the API again. See virDomainGetMemoryParameters() for more details.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: params
arg.info: pointer to block stats parameter object (return value)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of block stats; input and output

function.name: virDomainCoreDump
function.info:
This method will dump the core of a domain on a given file for analysis. Note that for remote Xen Daemon the file path will be interpreted in the remote host. Hypervisors may require the user to manually ensure proper permissions on the file named by @to.
If @flags includes VIR_DUMP_CRASH, then leave the guest shut off with a crashed state after the dump completes. If @flags includes VIR_DUMP_LIVE, then make the core dump while continuing to allow the guest to run; otherwise, the guest is suspended during the dump. VIR_DUMP_RESET flag forces reset of the quest after dump. The above three flags are mutually exclusive.
Additionally, if @flags includes VIR_DUMP_BYPASS_CACHE, then libvirt will attempt to bypass the file system cache while creating the file, or fail if it cannot do so for the given system; this can allow less pressure on file system cache, but also risks slowing saves to NFS.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

function.name: virDomainCreate
function.info: Launch a defined domain. If the call succeeds the domain moves from the defined to the running domains pools. The domain will be paused only if restoring from managed state created from a paused domain. For more control, see virDomainCreateWithFlags().

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of error

function.name: virDomainCreateLinux
function.info: Deprecated after 0.4.6. Renamed to virDomainCreateXML() providing identical functionality. This existing name will left indefinitely for API compatibility.

return.info: a new domain object or NULL in case of failure

arg.name: xmlDesc
arg.info: string containing an XML description of the domain

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainCreateWithFlags
function.info:
Launch a defined domain. If the call succeeds the domain moves from the defined to the running domains pools.
If the VIR_DOMAIN_START_PAUSED flag is set, or if the guest domain has a managed save image that requested paused state (see virDomainManagedSave()) the guest domain will be started, but its CPUs will remain paused. The CPUs can later be manually started using virDomainResume(). In all other cases, the guest domain will be running.
If the VIR_DOMAIN_START_AUTODESTROY flag is set, the guest domain will be automatically destroyed when the virConnectPtr object is finally released. This will also happen if the client application crashes / loses its connection to the libvirtd daemon. Any domains marked for auto destroy will block attempts at migration, save-to-file, or snapshots.
If the VIR_DOMAIN_START_BYPASS_CACHE flag is set, and there is a managed save file for this domain (created by virDomainManagedSave()), then libvirt will attempt to bypass the file system cache while restoring the file, or fail if it cannot do so for the given system; this can allow less pressure on file system cache, but also risks slowing loads from NFS.
If the VIR_DOMAIN_START_FORCE_BOOT flag is set, then any managed save file for this domain is discarded, and the domain boots from scratch.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of error

function.name: virDomainCreateXML
function.info:
Launch a new guest domain, based on an XML description similar to the one returned by virDomainGetXMLDesc() This function may require privileged access to the hypervisor. The domain is not persistent, so its definition will disappear when it is destroyed, or if the host is restarted (see virDomainDefineXML() to define persistent domains).
If the VIR_DOMAIN_START_PAUSED flag is set, the guest domain will be started, but its CPUs will remain paused. The CPUs can later be manually started using virDomainResume.
If the VIR_DOMAIN_START_AUTODESTROY flag is set, the guest domain will be automatically destroyed when the virConnectPtr object is finally released. This will also happen if the client application crashes / loses its connection to the libvirtd daemon. Any domains marked for auto destroy will block attempts at migration, save-to-file, or snapshots.

return.info: a new domain object or NULL in case of failure

arg.name: xmlDesc
arg.info: string containing an XML description of the domain

function.name: virDomainDefineXML
function.info: Define a domain, but does not start it. This definition is persistent, until explicitly undefined with virDomainUndefine(). A previous definition for this domain would be overriden if it already exists.

return.info: NULL in case of error, a pointer to the domain otherwise

arg.name: xml
arg.info: the XML description for the domain, preferably in UTF-8

function.name: virDomainDestroy
function.info:
Destroy the domain object. The running instance is shutdown if not down already and all resources used by it are given back to the hypervisor. This does not free the associated virDomainPtr object. This function may require privileged access
virDomainDestroy first requests that a guest terminate (e.g. SIGTERM), then waits for it to comply. After a reasonable timeout, if the guest still exists, virDomainDestory will forcefully terminate the guest (e.g. SIGKILL) if necessary (which may produce undesirable results, for example unflushed disk cache in the guest). To avoid this possibility, it's recommended to instead call virDomainDestroyFlags, sending the VIR_DOMAIN_DESTROY_GRACEFUL flag.
If the domain is transient and has any snapshot metadata (see virDomainSnapshotNum()), then that metadata will automatically be deleted when the domain quits.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

function.name: virDomainDestroyFlags
function.info:
Destroy the domain object. The running instance is shutdown if not down already and all resources used by it are given back to the hypervisor. This does not free the associated virDomainPtr object. This function may require privileged access.
Calling this function with no @flags set (equal to zero) is equivalent to calling virDomainDestroy, and after a reasonable timeout will forcefully terminate the guest (e.g. SIGKILL) if necessary (which may produce undesirable results, for example unflushed disk cache in the guest). Including VIR_DOMAIN_DESTROY_GRACEFUL in the flags will prevent the forceful termination of the guest, and virDomainDestroyFlags will instead return an error if the guest doesn't terminate by the end of the timeout; at that time, the management application can decide if calling again without VIR_DOMAIN_DESTROY_GRACEFUL is appropriate.
Another alternative which may produce cleaner results for the guest's disks is to use virDomainShutdown() instead, but that depends on guest support (some hypervisor/guest combinations may ignore the shutdown request).

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

function.name: virDomainDetachDevice
function.info: Destroy a virtual device attachment to backend. This function, having hot-unplug semantics, is only allowed on an active domain.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: xml
arg.info: pointer to XML description of one device

function.name: virDomainDetachDeviceFlags
function.info: Detach a virtual device from a domain, using the flags parameter to control how the device is detached. VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CURRENT specifies that the device allocation is removed based on current domain state. VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_LIVE specifies that the device shall be deallocated from the active domain instance only and is not from the persisted domain configuration. VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CONFIG specifies that the device shall be deallocated from the persisted domain configuration only. Note that the target hypervisor must return an error if unable to satisfy flags. E.g. the hypervisor driver will return failure if LIVE is specified but it only supports removing the persisted device allocation.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: xml
arg.info: pointer to XML description of one device

function.name: virDomainFree
function.info: Free the domain object. The running instance is kept alive. The data structure is freed and should not be used thereafter.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

function.name: virDomainGetAutostart
function.info: Provides a boolean value indicating whether the domain configured to be automatically started when the host machine boots.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success

function.name: virDomainGetBlkioParameters
function.info:
Get all blkio parameters. On input, @nparams gives the size of the @params array; on output, @nparams gives how many slots were filled with parameter information, which might be less but will not exceed the input value.
As a special case, calling with @params as NULL and @nparams as 0 on input will cause @nparams on output to contain the number of parameters supported by the hypervisor. The caller should then allocate @params array, i.e. (sizeof(@virTypedParameter) * @nparams) bytes and call the API again.
See virDomainGetMemoryParameters() for an equivalent usage example.
This function may require privileged access to the hypervisor. This function expects the caller to allocate the @params.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: params
arg.info: pointer to blkio parameter object (return value, allocated by the caller)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of blkio parameters; input and output

function.name: virDomainGetBlockInfo
function.info:
Extract information about a domain's block device.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or (since 0.9.5) the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: info
arg.info: pointer to a virDomainBlockInfo structure allocated by the user

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainGetBlockIoTune
function.info:
Get all block IO tunable parameters for a given device. On input, @nparams gives the size of the @params array; on output, @nparams gives how many slots were filled with parameter information, which might be less but will not exceed the input value.
As a special case, calling with @params as NULL and @nparams as 0 on input will cause @nparams on output to contain the number of parameters supported by the hypervisor, either for the given @disk (note that block devices of different types might support different parameters), or if @disk is NULL, for all possible disks. The caller should then allocate @params array, i.e. (sizeof(@virTypedParameter) * @nparams) bytes and call the API again. See virDomainGetMemoryParameters() for more details.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk. This parameter cannot be NULL unless @nparams is 0 on input.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: params
arg.info: Pointer to blkio parameter object (return value, allocated by the caller)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: Pointer to number of blkio parameters

function.name: virDomainGetBlockJobInfo
function.info:
Request block job information for the given disk. If an operation is active @info will be updated with the current progress.
The @disk parameter is either an unambiguous source name of the block device (the <source file='...'/> sub-element, such as "/path/to/image"), or (since 0.9.5) the device target shorthand (the <target dev='...'/> sub-element, such as "xvda"). Valid names can be found by calling virDomainGetXMLDesc() and inspecting elements within //domain/devices/disk.

return.info: -1 in case of failure, 0 when nothing found, 1 when info was found.

arg.name: disk
arg.info: path to the block device, or device shorthand

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainGetCPUStats
function.info:
Get statistics relating to CPU usage attributable to a single domain (in contrast to the statistics returned by virNodeGetCPUStats() for all processes on the host). @dom must be running (an inactive domain has no attributable cpu usage). On input, @params must contain at least @nparams * @ncpus entries, allocated by the caller.
If @start_cpu is -1, then @ncpus must be 1, and the returned results reflect the statistics attributable to the entire domain (such as user and system time for the process as a whole). Otherwise, @start_cpu represents which cpu to start with, and @ncpus represents how many consecutive processors to query, with statistics attributable per processor (such as per-cpu usage). If @ncpus is larger than the number of cpus available to query, then the trailing part of the array will be unpopulated.
The remote driver imposes a limit of 128 @ncpus and 16 @nparams; the number of parameters per cpu should not exceed 16, but if you have a host with more than 128 CPUs, your program should split the request into multiple calls.
As special cases, if @params is NULL and @nparams is 0 and @ncpus is 1, and the return value will be how many statistics are available for the given @start_cpu. This number may be different for @start_cpu of -1 than for any non-negative value, but will be the same for all non-negative @start_cpu. Likewise, if @params is NULL and @nparams is 0 and @ncpus is 0, the number of cpus available to query is returned. From the host perspective, this would typically match the cpus member of virNodeGetInfo(), but might be less due to host cpu hotplug.
For now, @flags is unused, and the statistics all relate to the usage from the host perspective. It is possible that a future version will support a flag that queries the cpu usage from the guest's perspective, where the maximum cpu to query would be related to virDomainGetVcpusFlags() rather than virNodeGetInfo(). An individual guest vcpu cannot be reliably mapped back to a specific host cpu unless a single-processor vcpu pinning was used, but when @start_cpu is -1, any difference in usage between a host and guest perspective would serve as a measure of hypervisor overhead.
Typical use sequence is below.
getting total stats: set start_cpu as -1, ncpus 1 virDomainGetCPUStats(dom, NULL, 0, -1, 1, 0) => nparams params = calloc(nparams, sizeof(virTypedParameter)) virDomainGetCPUStats(dom, params, nparams, -1, 1, 0) => total stats.
getting per-cpu stats: virDomainGetCPUStats(dom, NULL, 0, 0, 0, 0) => ncpus virDomainGetCPUStats(dom, NULL, 0, 0, 1, 0) => nparams params = calloc(ncpus * nparams, sizeof(virTypedParameter)) virDomainGetCPUStats(dom, params, nparams, 0, ncpus, 0) => per-cpu stats

return.info: -1 on failure, or the number of statistics that were populated per cpu on success (this will be less than the total number of populated @params, unless @ncpus was 1; and may be less than @nparams). The populated parameters start at each stride of @nparams, which means the results may be discontiguous; any unpopulated parameters will be zeroed on success (this includes skipped elements if @nparams is too large, and tail elements if @ncpus is too large). The caller is responsible for freeing any returned string parameters.

arg.name: start_cpu
arg.info: which cpu to start with, or -1 for summary

function.name: virDomainGetConnect
function.info:
Provides the connection pointer associated with a domain. The reference counter on the connection is not increased by this call.
WARNING: When writing libvirt bindings in other languages, do not use this function. Instead, store the connection and the domain object together.

return.info: the virConnectPtr or NULL in case of failure.

function.name: virDomainGetControlInfo
function.info: Extract details about current state of control interface to a domain.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: info
arg.info: pointer to a virDomainControlInfo structure allocated by the user

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainGetDiskErrors
function.info:
The function populates @errors array with all disks that encountered an I/O error. Disks with no error will not be returned in the @errors array. Each disk is identified by its target (the dev attribute of target subelement in domain XML), such as "vda", and accompanied with the error that was seen on it. The caller is also responsible for calling free() on each disk name returned.
In a special case when @errors is NULL and @maxerrors is 0, the function

return.info: preferred size of @errors that the caller should use to get all disk errors. Since calling virDomainGetDiskErrors(dom, NULL, 0, 0) to get preferred size of @errors array and getting the errors are two separate operations, new disks may be hotplugged to the domain and new errors may be encountered between the two calls. Thus, this function may not return all disk errors because the supplied array is not large enough. Such errors may, however, be detected by listening to domain events. Returns number of disks with errors filled in the @errors array or -1 on error.

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainGetID
function.info: Get the hypervisor ID number for the domain

return.info: the domain ID number or (unsigned int) -1 in case of error

function.name: virDomainGetInfo
function.info: Extract information about a domain. Note that if the connection used to get the domain is limited only a partial set of the information can be extracted.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: info
arg.info: pointer to a virDomainInfo structure allocated by the user

function.name: virDomainGetInterfaceParameters
function.info:
Get all interface parameters. On input, @nparams gives the size of the @params array; on output, @nparams gives how many slots were filled with parameter information, which might be less but will not exceed the input value.
As a special case, calling with @params as NULL and @nparams as 0 on input will cause @nparams on output to contain the number of parameters supported by the hypervisor. The caller should then allocate @params array, i.e. (sizeof(@virTypedParameter) * @nparams) bytes and call the API again. See virDomainGetMemoryParameters() for an equivalent usage example.
This function may require privileged access to the hypervisor. This function expects the caller to allocate the @params.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: device
arg.info: the interface name or mac address

arg.name: params
arg.info: pointer to interface parameter objects (return value, allocated by the caller)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of interface parameter; input and output

function.name: virDomainGetJobInfo
function.info: Extract information about progress of a background job on a domain. Will return an error if the domain is not active.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: info
arg.info: pointer to a virDomainJobInfo structure allocated by the user

function.name: virDomainGetMaxMemory
function.info: Retrieve the maximum amount of physical memory allocated to a domain. If domain is NULL, then this get the amount of memory reserved to Domain0 i.e. the domain where the application runs.

return.info: the memory size in kibibytes (blocks of 1024 bytes), or 0 in case of error.

function.name: virDomainGetMaxVcpus
function.info: Provides the maximum number of virtual CPUs supported for the guest VM. If the guest is inactive, this is basically the same as virConnectGetMaxVcpus(). If the guest is running this will reflect the maximum number of virtual CPUs the guest was booted with. For more details, see virDomainGetVcpusFlags().

return.info: the maximum of virtual CPU or -1 in case of error.

function.name: virDomainGetMemoryParameters

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: params
arg.info: pointer to memory parameter object (return value, allocated by the caller)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of memory parameters; input and output

function.name: virDomainGetMetadata

return.info: the metadata string on success (caller must free), or NULL in case of failure.

function.name: virDomainGetName
function.info: Get the public name for that domain

return.info: a pointer to the name or NULL, the string need not be deallocated its lifetime will be the same as the domain object.

function.name: virDomainGetNumaParameters
function.info:
Get all numa parameters. On input, @nparams gives the size of the @params array; on output, @nparams gives how many slots were filled with parameter information, which might be less but will not exceed the input value.
As a special case, calling with @params as NULL and @nparams as 0 on input will cause @nparams on output to contain the number of parameters supported by the hypervisor. The caller should then allocate @params array, i.e. (sizeof(@virTypedParameter) * @nparams) bytes and call the API again.
See virDomainGetMemoryParameters() for an equivalent usage example.
This function may require privileged access to the hypervisor. This function expects the caller to allocate the @params.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: params
arg.info: pointer to numa parameter object (return value, allocated by the caller)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of numa parameters

function.name: virDomainGetOSType
function.info: Get the type of domain operation system.

return.info: the new string or NULL in case of error, the string must be freed by the caller.

function.name: virDomainGetSchedulerParameters
function.info:
Get all scheduler parameters. On input, @nparams gives the size of the @params array; on output, @nparams gives how many slots were filled with parameter information, which might be less but will not exceed the input value. @nparams cannot be 0.
It is hypervisor specific whether this returns the live or persistent state; for more control, use virDomainGetSchedulerParametersFlags().

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: params
arg.info: pointer to scheduler parameter objects (return value)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of scheduler parameter objects (this value should generally be as large as the returned value nparams of virDomainGetSchedulerType()); input and output

function.name: virDomainGetSchedulerParametersFlags

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success.

arg.name: params
arg.info: pointer to scheduler parameter object (return value)

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of scheduler parameter (this value should be same than the returned value nparams of virDomainGetSchedulerType()); input and output

function.name: virDomainGetSchedulerType
function.info: Get the scheduler type and the number of scheduler parameters.

return.info: NULL in case of error. The caller must free the returned string.

arg.name: nparams
arg.info: pointer to number of scheduler parameters, can be NULL (return value)

function.name: virDomainGetSecurityLabel
function.info: Extract security label of an active domain. The 'label' field in the @seclabel argument will be initialized to the empty string if the domain is not running under a security model.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of failure

function.name: virDomainGetState
function.info: Extract domain state. Each state can be accompanied with a reason (if known) which led to the state.

return.info: 0 in case of success and -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: state
arg.info: returned state of the domain (one of virDomainState)

arg.name: reason
arg.info: returned reason which led to @state (one of virDomain*Reason corresponding to the current state); it is allowed to be NULL

arg.name: flags
arg.info: extra flags; not used yet, so callers should always pass 0

function.name: virDomainGetUUID
function.info: Get the UUID for a domain

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success

arg.name: uuid
arg.info: pointer to a VIR_UUID_BUFLEN bytes array

function.name: virDomainGetUUIDString
function.info: Get the UUID for a domain as string. For more information about UUID see RFC4122.

return.info: -1 in case of error, 0 in case of success

arg.name: buf
arg.info: pointer to a VIR_UUID_STRING_BUFLEN bytes array

function.name: virDomainGetVcpuPinInfo
function.info: Query the CPU affinity setting of all virtual CPUs of domain, store it in cpumaps.

return.info: the number of virtual CPUs in case of success, -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: domain
arg.info: pointer to domain object, or NULL for Domain0

arg.name: ncpumaps
arg.info: the number of cpumap (listed first to match virDomainGetVcpus)

arg.name: cpumaps
arg.info: pointer to a bit map of real CPUs for all vcpus of this domain (in 8-bit bytes) (OUT) It's assumed there is <ncpumaps> cpumap in cpumaps array. The memory allocated to cpumaps must be (ncpumaps * maplen) bytes (ie: calloc(ncpumaps, maplen)). One cpumap inside cpumaps has the format described in virDomainPinVcpu() API. Must not be NULL.

arg.name: maplen
arg.info: the number of bytes in one cpumap, from 1 up to size of CPU map. Must be positive.

arg.name: flags
arg.info: bitwise-OR of virDomainModificationImpact Must not be VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_LIVE and VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CONFIG concurrently.

function.name: virDomainGetVcpus
function.info:
Extract information about virtual CPUs of domain, store it in info array and also in cpumaps if this pointer isn't NULL. This call may fail on an inactive domain.
See also virDomainGetVcpuPinInfo for querying just cpumaps, including on an inactive domain.

return.info: the number of info filled in case of success, -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: domain
arg.info: pointer to domain object, or NULL for Domain0

arg.name: info
arg.info: pointer to an array of virVcpuInfo structures (OUT)

arg.name: maxinfo
arg.info: number of structures in info array

arg.name: cpumaps
arg.info: pointer to a bit map of real CPUs for all vcpus of this domain (in 8-bit bytes) (OUT) If cpumaps is NULL, then no cpumap information is returned by the API. It's assumed there is <maxinfo> cpumap in cpumaps array. The memory allocated to cpumaps must be (maxinfo * maplen) bytes (ie: calloc(maxinfo, maplen)). One cpumap inside cpumaps has the format described in virDomainPinVcpu() API.

arg.name: maplen
arg.info: number of bytes in one cpumap, from 1 up to size of CPU map in underlying virtualization system (Xen...). Must be zero when cpumaps is NULL and positive when it is non-NULL.

function.name: virDomainGetVcpusFlags
function.info:
Query the number of virtual CPUs used by the domain. Note that this call may fail if the underlying virtualization hypervisor does not support it. This function may require privileged access to the hypervisor.
If @flags includes VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_LIVE, this will query a running domain (which will fail if domain is not active); if it includes VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CONFIG, this will query the XML description of the domain. It is an error to set both flags. If neither flag is set (that is, VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CURRENT), then the configuration queried depends on whether the domain is currently running.
If @flags includes VIR_DOMAIN_VCPU_MAXIMUM, then the maximum virtual CPU limit is queried. Otherwise, this call queries the current virtual CPU limit.

return.info: 0 in case of success, -1 in case of failure.

arg.name: domain
